abstract.text: This Tracker presents data on daily COVID-19 cases at the sub-national level for 26 European countries from January 2020 till present. Country-level data sources are identified and processed to form a homogenized panel at the NUTS 3 or NUTS 2 level, the two lowest standardized administrative units of Europe. The strengths and weaknesses of each country dataset are discussed in detail. The raw data, spatial layers, the code, and the final homogenized files are provided in an online repository for replication. The data highlights the spatial distribution of cases both within and across countries that can be utilized for a disaggregated analysis on the impacts of the pandemic. The Tracker is updated monthly to expand its coverage. 9

body_text.text: COVID-19 cases exploded in Europe around early March 2020. At the center of this spread were the regions of North 23 Italy 6 and the ski resort of Ishgl in the western part of Austria. 7 From this point onward, the virus quickly spread across the 24 European continent, resulting in a rapid increase in cases and deaths, and alarming governments that implemented stringent 25 lockdown measures including border closures, reductions in mobility, to shutting down the economy. 8 While the virus was 26 mostly contained during the summer of 2020, a resurgence in cases in the Fall of 2020 resulted in a massive second wave that 27 completely overshadowed the first wave in terms of cases and deaths. In order to contain the virus, a second round of lockdown 28 measures were put in place around October 2020. 9 Currently, in early 2021, the detection of more infectious virus variants, and 29 a slower-than-expected vaccine roll-out in Europe has prompted countries to further extend their lockdown measures. As Figure   30 1 shows, no other continent has borne the brunt of the virus as Europe which still has a major share in global cases and deaths. 31 A unique feature of the COVID-19 pandemic is the amount of knowledge and data that is constantly being generated 32 to understand how this event unfolds. For a high-income region like Europe, the quality of information that is generated 33 on a daily basis is exceptionally high for most countries. Furthermore, several innovative datasets have appeared since the 34 start of the pandemic that provide unique information. For example, the Oxford COVID-19 Government Response Tracker 10 35 and the Complexity Science Hub (CSH) Tracker 11 evaluate daily policy changes for a host of indicators for all countries of together with the extent of the errors. Regardless of the minor matching issues in the homogenized dataset, raw data is also 97 available in case the users prefer to use the original source of information. 98 Second, some countries use different types of administrative divisions for regional tracking of COVID-19 cases that do not 99 have an official correspondence to NUTS classifications. For example, Finland uses Hospital Districts, Greece uses Prefectures, 100 Norway uses Kommunes, and the UK reports at the Local Authority Districts (LADs). This issue is resolved by overlaying the 101 different administrative regions with NUTS boundaries to generate a spatial crosswalk or a region-to-NUTS mapping. For 102 Greece, Norway, and the UK the regions map perfectly to NUTS boundaries while for Finland, small errors persist in some 103 regions. These are also highlighted and discussed in the Technical Validation section. GitHub repository, https://github.com/asjadnaqvi/COVID19-European-Regional-Tracker, is updated 111 once a month to expand its temporal coverage, and fix errors and bugs if any. 112 For each country two sets of data files are provided. The first set contains the raw data files downloaded from various 113 sources. These files include the records as they exist in the original data including the information on the spatial unit at which 114 the information is released. Most countries provided data at a administrative units below NUTS 3 (see Table 1 ). Furthermore, 115 most of the raw files contain more information than in the final data set homogenized at the NUTS level which contains 116 cumulative and daily cases information, the baseline variables that exist in all country files. Additional variables in the raw data 117 for example, include deaths, recovered, tested, hospitalized, and vaccinated. Some countries also provide age and gender-wise 118 breakdowns. Therefore, users of this Tracker can go deeper with their analysis by compiling a finer resolution and more detailed 119 dataset for analysis. The second set are the processed country files that map and convert the raw data into homogenized datasets 120 at the NUTS level. This mapping is done using Stata scripts or dofiles, which also identify the region-to-NUTS mapping. If 121 Stata is not available, the dofiles can be viewed with any generic text editor. The code structure is fairly straightforward to read 122 and can be easily converted to other programming languages. The files homogenized at the NUTS level are ready for analysis 123 and can be merged with other NUTS-level datasets available on Eurostat 3 for example.

The files on GitHub . CC-BY 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. (which was not certified by peer review)

The folders are described as follows:

• 01_raw contains miscellaneous country-level files. Each country has its own sub-folder with all the files necessary 130 to generate a clean version of the raw and homogenized data. These folders also include various files that help map 131 region identifiers to NUTS classifications. The raw data itself is saved in a Stata .dta format and the generic .csv file 132 format in the 04_master folder. The LAU folder contains the LAU 2019-to-NUTS 2016 correspondence file 2 from which 133 several country-level files are extracted where necessary. The Eurostat folder contains the cleaned regional population 134 file, downloaded from https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/databrowser/view/demo_r_pjangrp3/. 135 OWID contains data from the Our World in Data 12 GitHub repository, which is used for validating the Tracker.

• 02_dofiles contains the Stata scripts called dofiles for each country, and five additional dofiles that compile, merge, map, 137 and validate the data (see the Code Availability section for details). The dofiles are also version controlled (_v1, _v2, 138 _v3 etc.) to track changes in data sources and data structures. Only the latest dofile for each country is uploaded to the 139 repository. Each country dofile saves the raw data, and processes the raw data to created the homogenized file, both of 140 which are saved in the 04_master folder. See the Code Availability section for details on how to run these files.

• 03_GIS contains the raw and processed GIS files. The raw NUTS 0 to NUTS 3 2016 shapefiles are downloaded from the 142 Eurostat GISCO website https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/gisco/geodata/reference-data/ 143 administrative-units-statistical-units/nuts. 15 and processed using the COUNTRY_GIS_setup.do 144 in the 02_dofiles folder.
• 04_master contains the raw and the homogenized country files, and the final dataset EUROPE_COVID19_master.dta.
The .csv versions of the the raw and homogenized files are saved in the csv_original and csv_nuts folders respectively.
• 05_figures contains the maps and figures generated from various dofiles.

The main data file "COVID19_master.dta" and it's .csv version are given in the 04_master folder. The master files contain 149 the following variables with their description given in brackets: Each country is briefly discussed below and data challenges are highlighted:

• Austria: Austria currently provides daily updates at the district (Bezirk) level, a tier below NUTS 3. The data can be 169 downloaded directly from the official website as a zipped file from which the relevant file is extracted and processed. . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted February 17, 2021. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.02.15.21251788 doi: medRxiv preprint • Belgium: Belgium provides daily updates and the data file can be read directly from the website. Regions with cases 5 or 171 below are labeled as ≤5 for privacy reasons. As a judgement call, to keep the variable numeric, these values have been 172 replaced with 1. Users can refer to the original data or change the dofiles if a different way of dealing with ranges is 173 preferred.
• Croatia: Croatia provides official data at the NUTS 3 level in a JSON format which is processed directly in Stata.
• Czechia: Czechia data is imported directly from the official website for processing.

• Denmark: Denmark releases a zipped file daily which is imported and processed directly in Stata. Data is split across 177 several files from which only the one containing information on cases is used.

• Estonia: Estonia officially releases the data on COVID-19 but in order to maintain privacy, data is only provided in 179 ranges of 10s, for example, 10-20, 20-30, 100-110, etc. In order to make this variable numeric, the mid-points of these 180 ranges are taken, and aggregated at the NUTS 3 level. Using mid-points is a judgement call to make the cases variable 181 numeric. The raw data file contains the original information which can be processed differently if needed.
• Finland: The data for Finland is taken from a GitHub repository that scrapes the data and provides it in a JSON format.

This is read and parsed in Stata. This data is at the hospital district level which does not perfectly correspond to NUTS 3 184 boundaries. Therefore errors persist in the final data file. See Technical validation section for detailed notes.

• France: France provides a comprehensive range of COVID-19 related indicators on its official website. France also 186 switched methodologies for improving the data quality in May 2020. Old data is available online and has been merged 187 with the current data but the quality is poor. Data of territories outside of mainland Europe have been dropped. The file is 188 downloaded manually from the website for processing.

• Germany: Germany's data, provided by the Robert Koch Institute (RKI), has been of really high quality data since the 190 early days of the pandemic. Several repositories of this data exist on GitHub, of which, one has been selected for the 191 Tracker.

• Greece: Greece only releases PDFs which contain information at the prefecture level. This information is downloaded 193 from a GitHub repository that scrapes the PDFs. The data which is at the prefecture level, matches perfectly to NUTS 2 194 boundaries. Autonomous islands of Greece are dropped from the homogenized dataset but they exist in the raw file.

• Hungary: Hungary does not officially release any data. A map is uploaded in an image format on the official website 196 https://koronavirus.gov.hu/, which is scrapped daily by independent users. This information is retrieved 197 from a GitHub repository.
• Ireland: Ireland releases regional data on ArcGIS Hub which is downloaded manually for processing. The links are 199 provided in the Stata script.

• Italy: Italy has one of the best data-sharing setup among the European countries. Italy currently provides full docu-201 mentation and access to their data on their official GitHub page https://github.com/pcm-dpc/COVID-19.

The regions defined in the data perfectly match NUTS 2021 definitions but the aggregation to NUTS 2016 has to be 203 approximated for three small island regions since their boundaries were modified. See Technical Validation sector for 204 details.

• Latvia: Latvia updates the data daily which can be downloaded directly from the official website. Regions with cases 206 under 5 are displayed with a range of 1-5 for privacy reasons. This has been replaced with a value of one to keep the 207 variable numeric. The raw file containing the original information can used to process these ranges differently.
• Netherlands: Netherlands data is downloaded directly from the official website for processing.

• Norway: Since Norway is outside of the EU, no consistent information at the NUTS 3 level is available. The Norwegian 210 data, which is provided at the Kommune level which is one tier below NUTS 3. This data is spatially joined with the

body_text.text: • Portugal: The official regional data for Portugal is off poor quality. Data on regions was released on a daily frequency till July 2020, and then it was switched to a weekly frequency. Currently information is only available on a bi-weekly basis.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Out of all the countries in the Tracker, Portugal's data is the least usable but is kept in the dataset since the information is 219 provided at the NUTS 3 level.
• Romania: The official data for Romania is available in JSON format which is converted into a CSV format for processing 221 in Stata. The links are provided in the Stata script for Romania.
• Slovak Republic: The data for Slovak Republic is downloaded from a GitHub repository which processes and cleans the 223 official data.
• Slovenia: The data for Slovenia is downloaded from a GitHub repository which processes and cleans the official data.
• Spain: Spain's data is downloaded directly from the official website.
• Sweden: Sweden releases a file daily which is manually downloaded. The link is provided in Table 3 and in the data
-North Ireland: Data for North Ireland has not been found at a consistent regional-day resolution in a machine-249 readable format.
-Wales: Data for Wales has not been found at a consistent regional-day resolution in a machine-readable format.

The following countries -Albania, Bosnia, Bulgaria, Serbia, Lithuania, North Ireland (UK), North Macedonia, Turkey, 252 and Wales (UK), have official NUTS 3 correspondence tables but are not currently in the Tracker since their regional data has 253 not been located. If these countries have to be included with the current data version, they can be replaced with country-level . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted February 17, 2021. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.02.15.21251788 doi: medRxiv preprint Figure 6 shows the cumulative distribution of cases and cases per 10,000 population for the complete date ranging from 263 15 January 2020 till 9 February 2021. Here we can immediately observe that larger units in terms of area have more cases 264 overall than smaller ones. If we control for population size then a different picture emerges. For example, it is clear from the 265 cumulative cases per 10,000 population map that Germany managed to insulate itself very well from neighboring countries by 266 enforcing strict border controls. Despite this, regions on the east side show a higher incidence rate than the west and north 267 Germany. Similarly the western part of Austria, north Italy, Switzerland, and eastern part of France have a much higher level 268 of cases per capita relative to the remaining regions in these countries. Sweden with its lack of strict lockdown policies also 269 stands out among the Nordic countries. Explanations for these trends are left as research questions. Furthermore, given the 270 daily resolution of the data in the Tracker, these maps can also be checked for variations in the first and the second waves. First, since the country-level datasets are official records provided by different government departments of each country, 275 they can be compared with various online dashboards highlighted in Table 2 . It is also important to point out that not all 276 countries release the latest data at the regional level. A good example of this is France, that releases a file daily but the regional 277 information is usually two to three days old. Similarly the crowd-sourced data for Switzerland, is back-filled data as information Second, as discussed earlier, regional data is approximated during the homogenization process for some countries. In order 281 to ensure transparency, Table 3 provides notes for various countries where either data is converted from ranges into unique 282 values (for example, Belgium, Estonia, and Latvia) or boundaries are approximated using a spatial merge (for example, Finland, Third, since the data is at the regional level, it can be aggregated up to generate country-level totals which can be compared 301 with data aggregator websites like the Our World in Data (OWID) COVID-19 tracker. OWID is used and referenced almost 302 daily in scientific research and the media and has a major impact of policy discussions. OWID was utilizing country-level 303 information provided by the European Center for Disease Control (ECDC) till November 2020. In November 2020, ECDC 304 announced that it only do bi-weekly data releases. As a response OWID switched to the John Hopkins University's (JHU) data 305 repository, a major data source for COVID-19 information at the global level. 1 For validation, both this Tracker and OWID data 306 is merged on a country-date combination and the difference between the country-level daily cases is calculated. Figure 7 plots 307 the difference split by countries. Figure 7 shows a how good the match is before 1 October 2020. After October 2020, the 308 mismatch for most countries increases significantly and persists till today. This highlights two points. First, before October 309 2020, data was provided by ECDC which was taking information directly from European countries. Since this Tracker is also 310 pulling data from the countries directly, the match is exceptionally close with the exception of some outliers. This exercise 311 helps validate the data of this Tracker. Second, since the data source of this Tracker remains the same, while OWID changed 312 its source to a more unverified data set around October 2020, this Tracker provides a more accurate picture of country-level 313 aggregates and also includes regional variation. 314 1 See the press release here https://ourworldindata.org/covid-data-switch-jhu.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted February 17, 2021. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.02.15.21251788 doi: medRxiv preprint Usage Notes 315 The dataset has been compiled in Stata (www.stata.com) 16 , a standard statistical software mostly used in the field of 316 economics. All data including raw files, scripts, and the final data set are provided on GitHub 1 . Besides the Stata .dta data 317 format, all information is also stored in the generic .csv format allowing the data to be accessed in any software. Annotated 318 Stata scripts, or dofiles are also provided. Stata has an easy-to-interpret syntax structure that can be easily translated into other 319 programming languages.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: As a caveat, there are two features that Stata cannot handle well. First, is the ability to download files that are redirected 321 from clicks or links on websites. This level of web-scraping works much better in other languages designed for such tasks like 322 R or Python. Second data in JSON format has to be parsed either manually using user-written commands, or via third-party 323 JSON-to-csv converters that are available online. Processing complex data structures like JSON or XML are also easier in other 324 languages.

The repository is updated approximately every four weeks including a public release on Zenodo. If users prefer a higher 326 frequency of updates, then the Stata scripts can be used directly to process the files or a more frequent release can be requested 327 as well. Since the aim of the homogenized dataset is to be able to correlated it with existing NUTS level datasets, a monthly 328 frequency is sufficient since European-level regional data takes several weeks or even months to be updated. . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted February 17, 2021. ; Table 3 . Notes on countries with data or mapping issues The data is provided at the Hospital District level. These do not correspond perfectly to NUTS 3 regions. See Figure 5b for reference and the raw file for the original data. An official spatial map of hospital districts is not readily available. The official website also shows municipality level data but this has not been found collated in any repository. The data correspondence to NUTS 2 2016 definitions for all regions except Warsaw (PL90) which is manually duplicated to PL91 and PL92. The values are d. The data file switches from cumulative to daily cases in the same column after 23 November 2020. This is manually fixed in the NUTS 2 file. Data errors exist for 13th June 2020 which are manually fixed by taking the average of the previous and the next date. See raw file for original data. The official website now provides NUTS 3 level data but the range in limited.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Portugal switched to releasing regional data at weekly intervals after 7th July 2020. From 26 October 2020 the reporting range was increased to 14 day intervals. Therefore daily cases data is mostly limited to pre-July 2020 values. Only the daily cases reported in the weekly or bi-weekly data are added to the homogenized tracker. Please see the raw data and the https://github.com/dssg-pt/ covid19pt-data for detailed documentation.

Yes Data for each Swiss canton, that match perfectly to NUTS 3 regions, is released separately and volunteer groups aggregate this information. Therefore, there are variations on the frequency of updated across the cantons. See original file for details.

UK now has an official API server for data queries but there are limits to how much data can be extracted. Currently the data aggregator website Our World in Data is the only source providing LAU level information for UK, but this is only available at a 7-day rolling average normalized by population (https://ourworldindata.org/local-covid-uk). Bulk micro regional data has not been publicly released.

No NUTS 3 correspondence is extracted using a spatial merge between the Local Authority Districts (LADs) using April 2019 definitions and NUTS 3 2016 boundaries. See Figure 5a for details and see raw file for the original data.

FIGREF0.text: for the tracker has been made publicly available on Zenodo under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International 106 Licence (CC-BY). The latest version of the repository can be accessed using the Zenodo DOI: https://doi.org/10. 107 5281/zenodo.4244878. 1 The Tracker data shown in this paper shows the evolution of cases in European regions from 15 108 January 2020 till 9 February 2021. Since the COVID-19 virus started spreading in Europe around March 2020, the panel of the 109 country-regions-date is fairly complete from April 2020 onward. Figure 3 summarizes the exact date range for each country. The110

FIGREF2.text: 211NUTS 2016 boundaries to create a Kommune-to-NUTS 3 crosswalk which results in a perfect mapping. See section on 212 Technical Validation for details.213• Poland: Poland data is extracted from a GitHub repository that extracts NUTS 2 level data. Poland launched its data 214 sharing service relatively recently which currently also provides NUTS 3 level, but it does not have the temporal extent to 215 fit in this Tracker.

FIGREF4.text: Switzerland: Switzerland does not have country-wide information available in a centralized place. Instead, a group 229 of independent researchers collate this information from the official websites of the various Cantons, which are also 230 NUTS 3 regions. Therefore the very latest data is not immediately available. United Kingdom: The data for UK is not easily accessible, neither it is well documented. Despite shifting to a new 232 website in the summer of 2020, information is only released for 7-day intervals for regions below NUTS 3 in the form 233 of an interactive map, https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/interactive-map. Furthermore, 234 the data portal for the UK https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/download has put significant 235 restrictions on bulk downloading. Therefore, UK is dealt with as four separate countries; England, North Ireland, 236 Scotland, and Wales. 237 -England: In the early days of the pandemic, Tom White put an enormous amount of effort to collate UK 238 information from various sources. He efforts were later picked up by ODI Leeds (https://github.com/ 239 odileeds/covid-19-uk-datasets) that now update the dataset for England. The data is available at 240 the Local Authority Districts (LAD) using April 2019 definitions which can be found here. LADs aggregate up 241 perfectly to NUTS 3 2016 boundaries. More recent mapping of LADs-to-NUTS 3 can also be done but this would 242 require a significant effort to map the old identifiers to the new ones. See the section Technical Validation for 243 details.

FIGREF5.text: Scotland: Data for Scotland is available on their official website which is also processed by ODI Leeds (https: 245 //github.com/odileeds/covid-19-uk-datasets). Scotland's data is processed following the same 246 routine as England where LAD April 2019 boundaries are mapped on to NUTS 3 using a spatial merge. See the 247 section Technical Validation for details.

As a note of caution, the above information and descriptions are subject to change as countries evolve 256 their COVID-19 data sharing strategies. Please check the GitHub page for the latest updates.

FIGREF7.text: shows the data points available for each country. Here one can note major gaps in Portugal, Greece, and Estonia daily 259 cases data but on average the remaining countries are fairly complete. For the data used there are over 402,000 data points.260Individual NUTS-level cases per 10,000 population are plotted inFigure 4. In this figure we can also observe the difference in 261 normalized daily new cases between the first and the second waves. The spread goes up significantly in the second wave.

FIGREF9.text: have been taken to ensure that veracity and accuracy of the information and to document errors that might occur in 273 the homogenized file.

FIGREF11.text: 278 for the different regions (Cantons) is updated. Regardless of these lags, comparison of values with online dashboards is possible 279 for most countries in the Tracker.

FIGREF13.text: 283UK, Norway, and Greece). The data approximation error occurs when ranges are converted into unique numerical values. This 284 is a judgement call in order to allow these countries to merge with the remaining files. For Belgium and Latvia, regions with 285 cases less than five are anonymized as <5. These values have been replaced with 1. For Estonia, which only provides data 286 in ranges of 10s, mid values of each range is taken and multiplied with total cases to estimate cases per region, and then the 287 regions are aggregated to NUT 3. Therefore, the data approximation is the highest for Estonia. The raw data and the scripts are288 available in case users prefer the actual information or have other approximation strategies. For countries which do not have an 289 official correspondence to NUTS regions, a boundary approximation is done with a spatial merge by overlaying administrative 290 boundaries with NUTS boundaries. For UK, Norway and Greece, the spatial merge creates a perfect mapping as shown in For Finland, the hospital districts, that are size-wise comparable to NUTS 3 boundaries contains minor errors in some 292 cases since boundaries do not align. In an ideal case scenario, data should be provided at the smallest possible unit that can 293 be aggregated up to various administrative boundaries, as is the case with UK and Norway. The official Finish website does 294 provide COVID-19 data at municipality level, a unit below NUTS 3, but accessing the map is not straightforward nor it is clear 295 whether this data is even openly accessible. On a related note, Italy data is officially released at the NUTS 2021 definitions so 296 mapping to NUTS 2016 definitions do not work perfectly for some regions on an island off mainland Italy. These regions show 297 up as missing on the map. For both the Finnish and Italian regions that do not perfectly match, the number of cases are very 298 small for it to make a significant difference. Regardless, original administrative units and their data in the raw files and can be 299 used for more accuracy.

FIGREF15.text: Tracker can be utilized for a host of different research directions. For example, the Tracker can be mapped onto 330 NUTS-level regional data released by Eurostat 3 . This includes weekly or monthly economic indicators, demographic changes, 331 mortality indicators. Individual countries can also be analyzed if their statistical agencies provide regional or micro data for332 analysis. Other datasets catalogued on the Oxford COVID-19 Supertracker 13 provides a range of interesting information like 333 policy stringency indices, cross-border movement restrictions, health-related indicators etc. The Tracker data can also be 334 combined with several innovative global datasets which also contain NUTS-level information. This, for example, includes 335 Google Mobility trends 4 or the Facebook Social Connectivity Index 5 . Since, the data for the Tracker has a Creative Commons 336 Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC-BY), anyone can access it at any point in time, and it will get regular updates until 337the countries stop publishing regional COVID-19 data.

FIGREF16.text: code to process the files can be downloaded with the Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4244878) 340 repository or accessed from the Github repository. The code is written using Stata versions 15 and 16, which are also 341 recommended for improved functionality with maps and graphs but general data processing can be done in any version.342As specified in the Data Records section, the dofiles are in the /02 dofiles/ folder. Within this folder dofiles exist for each 343 country plus a set of five dofiles that setup, merge, map, and validate the final data file. These files are explained as follows:344• COUNTRY_SETUP.do initializes the code for running the country files. One can run each country file independently 345 as well, but they need the directory structure and packages to be loaded in order to function correctly. Directory and 346 packages can be initialized using the first few lines marked in the beginning of the COUNTRY_SETUP.do file. install cleanplots, from("https://tdmize.github.io/data/cleanplots") 361 set scheme cleanplots, perm 362 363 Each country .do file is annotated with notes where necessary.

FIGREF18.text: COUNTRY_GIS_setup.do sets up the GIS layers in Stata format for the combined NUTS regions and for individual 367 countries. A mixed NUTS3 and NUTS2 shapefile is also created accommodate the data from Poland and Greece. The 368 logic can also be applied to add data at the provincial (NUTS 1) or country (NUTS 0) level if one needs to add other 369 countries not in the dataset. This file also extracts shapefiles for individual countries and generates a file used for labeling 370 the individual country maps.371• COUNTRY_GIS_map.do create the maps that are saved in the 05_figures folder. SeeFigure 6for the overall map.372 Individual country COVID-19 maps can be viewed on GitHub. 373 • COUNTRY_validation.do collapses the Tracker to a country-date level and merges it with OWID COVID-19 dataset, for 374 validation. This file also produces Figure 7. 375 For the very latest version of the code, please also check GitHub. GitHub files will be converted in Zenodo repositories 376 approximately every four weeks. Each Zenodo release is assigned a unique DOIs, but the generic DOI https://doi.org/ 377 10.5281/zenodo.4244878 always link to the latest version.
